Triggering Event: A lone takeout box sits unclaimed at the restaurant's front door as she closes up for the night, its contents growing cold in the drafty lobby.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, what if someone gets sick from eating here?! What if they didn't have enough food in that box to survive?! What if they're still inside?! Seriously though, what if that girl just walked out with no idea how much time had passed? Maybe she was so busy that she forgot all about it. Or maybe she was too scared to come back. I wonder if she even tried calling us, or if she was just hoping we wouldn’t notice. You know what would be really terrible? If that poor girl got hurt because of our carelessness! She might have been waiting for her order for hours – you’d think she'd be hungry by now. But then again, maybe she got lost on her way home and is stuck somewhere else entirely. Yeah, what if she was already gone? Maybe she got into an accident on her way home, or maybe she slipped and fell somewhere else. The possibilities are endless! What if she was just trying to escape some bad situation? I swear, sometimes I feel like people can't handle a little responsibility. What if this whole thing was just one big mistake?! What if we get sued over this?! Ugh, my head is spinning! So, what if... *sigh*...we did nothing wrong? What if that girl is fine, just enjoying the rest of her evening somewhere else? What if she didn't even realize it was there?! What if she left the box outside by accident and never noticed?! What if

Triggering Event: He walked home from the hospital, the weight of another lost patient heavy on his shoulders. As he opened the front door, the quiet echoed with an emptiness that wasn't there yesterday. A note on the kitchen counter told him she had left for her mother's. No mention of when she'd return. He sat alone in their dark living room, her empty chair across from him, and cried quietly into his hands.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, I'm soooo shocked that he walked out of the house. I mean, who does that? That's just so random. I bet it was because he couldn't handle being around me anymore. Or maybe he just didn't want to deal with the stress of this job anymore. Maybe he wanted to get away from our family drama and start fresh somewhere else. Or maybe he just got bored with us and decided to move on. I bet he has some other girl waiting for him somewhere. And honestly, why would you expect anything less? We never really talk about how we feel anyway." "I'm literally shaking right now thinking about what might have happened. She could be anywhere, and it's probably not even safe for her to come back. But then again, why would she leave? Does she think I don't love her enough? Is she upset with something I said or did? Did I say or do something wrong? Am I not good enough for her? Why is she leaving like this?" "This is all so confusing! What if she doesn’t want to go back? What if she’s scared or stressed? What if she needs time alone? What if she’s already moved out? What if she’s just tired of everything and wants to escape it all? What if she left because I’m too much for her? What if she feels overwhelmed by life after this? What if she can't cope anymore?" Triggering Event: A slow, dreary drizzle starts as she closes up shop alone after another quiet day. She watches the raindrops streak down the dusty window panes, each one a tiny tributary to the puddle forming outside. Her reflection in the glass looks back at her, gray hair framing a face etched with lines of unhappiness. She turns away, flipping off the lights and leaving the empty store to its silent vigil until morning.
Generated Assessment: She's been feeling like this for months now - trapped between what she wants and what she can afford. The slow decline of her business is starting to show in every corner of her life. As she locks up her storefront, the weight of it all feels oppressive. It's hard to see how things will get better when everything seems stuck.

Triggering Event: A weary Dr. H., home after another grueling 14-hour shift, finds her husband's suitcase packed by the door. No note, no call, just an eerie emptiness echoing through their once-warm house.
Generated Assessment: "Ugh, here we go again. I swear, he’s always off somewhere for work. Can't stand it. I'm tired of being left behind. This time, it's like he vanished into thin air. I know he has a meeting at some fancy hotel in Vegas—yeah, right, like me, who gets to spend Christmas alone with my cat? He just goes out there, leaving me to deal with bills and laundry, all while pretending to care about what I have to say." "Doesn't matter if he makes money; does nothing to fill this hollow feeling. The worst part? His absence is like a punch to the gut every time. Like he doesn't even care that I've been working double shifts to keep everything together, making sure our daughter's college funds are secure. It's all so pointless when he just leaves. And don't even get me started on how he talks down to me because I’m stressed. You'd think he'd understand how hard it is to be patient and supportive. But no, he just keeps pushing me further away. I feel like he thinks he can just ignore me whenever he wants. Well, let me tell you, I won't be ignored." "I guess it's just another day in paradise. I'll make sure to throw him a welcome-back party, complete with balloons and cake. After all, that's what I do best. But honestly, I’d rather be spending my days shopping for myself than throwing

Triggering Event: In his lab after hours, he found her favorite notebook, its pages yellowed and worn, tucked behind a loose tile in the wall. He'd forgotten it was there, hidden years ago when she left for her fellowship abroad. Now, alone with the weight of her absence and the silence of their empty house, he traced her handwriting, each word a poignant reminder of her loss.
Generated Assessment: He's been living alone ever since she passed away, but the memories linger. The way she'd leave notes for him in the kitchen, the sound of her laughter echoing through our home. I still remember the day we said goodbye, standing at the airport as tears streamed down our faces. We promised to stay together, to rebuild our life, but now it feels like a distant dream. The things that happened before, they were always bad. She would get angry over nothing, and I couldn't stop her rage. I tried everything - talking sense, trying to calm her down, even resorting to anger myself - but she wouldn't listen. One night, I found her curled up in a ball, sobbing uncontrollably, and I didn't know what to do. I stayed with her until morning, holding her hand, trying to comfort her, but she just kept crying. She wasn’t the same woman anymore. Every time I saw her, I felt anxious, unsure if she’d be angry again. It’s hard to believe she loved me once, that she wanted to spend her life with me. All these thoughts keep flooding my mind, making it impossible to sleep. When I look around this empty room, I feel lost. There are no signs of her anymore - no books by her side, no flowers on the table, no hint of her presence. It’s as if she never lived here at all. I miss her so much, but every time I think about

Triggering Event: A slow afternoon at the store. He straightens a rack of ties, each one neatly folded over its hanger, like tiny, colored flags of surrender. His reflection in the glass case looks back at him, graying hair and lines etched deeper by the years. A young couple walks in, laughing, arms entwined. She picks up a tie, twirling it around her finger before handing it to him with a smile. They leave, still laughing, leaving behind an empty space on the rack and a hollow ache in his chest.
Generated Assessment: So what’s the big deal? You’re just standing there holding some ties, it’s a job. The woman comes along and buys a few, maybe even gives you a compliment, but it doesn’t matter. I’m too old for this stuff anyway, so why get worked up about a little thing like that? It’s just a sales pitch. Besides, she could’ve bought anything else from us, nothing special about those ties. And another customer will come along soon enough, and it’ll be the same story all over again. Just another day, another dollar, no need to get all worked up. You’re just going through the motions, getting older, and it’s time to stop wasting your energy on something as meaningless as trying to make a sale. You know what really bothers me? People thinking you actually care about selling them something when all you want is to go home. Like they can see right through you—just another tired old man who doesn’t care about anyone or anything anymore. That’s how it feels most days now. Even if someone does buy something, it’s just a temporary distraction from the fact that life has been slowly draining away your purpose since you were born. Maybe I should just take a break and sit down somewhere for a while. At least then I won’t have to pretend to care about whatever it is I’m supposed to be doing. But no, I keep pushing myself, stuck in this never-ending cycle of pretending to be interested in people

Triggering Event: She noticed his shirt draped over the chair in the living room, still warm from the heat of his body. The faint scent of her perfume lingered on the collar.
Generated Assessment: You know what I'm thinking right now? Like what if he just got out of bed? What if he was sleeping with some other woman? What if that's why she left him, because he had an affair? She has no idea how much it hurts to think about all this. It feels like there's nothing else to think about. So she keeps herself busy with little things, but deep down, she can't help wondering. And then she wonders again. Maybe she'll never be happy again. It's just so frustrating. You'd think that after everything she's been through, she wouldn't have these thoughts anymore. But here we are, stuck in this cycle of uncertainty. Even when she tries to convince herself otherwise, those doubts creep back in. She's starting to feel like she'll never find peace. And it's getting worse. Every time she sees his shirt, she feels like she's going crazy. Why does it haunt her so much? Is it really that hard to let go of the past? It doesn't seem like it is, yet she can't stop obsessing over what could've been. I don't even know why she's still holding on. Maybe it's just easier than facing reality. Whatever it is, it's not working. All she gets is more pain and sadness. There's always something to worry about. It's exhausting, but she can't seem to stop. Not when there's so much at stake. What if she loses

Triggering Event: A lone figure, his silhouette barely visible against the setting sun, stood by the school's playground swing set after hours. The cold wind whipped around him, but he seemed oblivious to it. His gaze was fixed on a small pendant hanging from the highest swing, swaying gently in the breeze. It was her favorite necklace, the one she always wore. He had forgotten about it until today, when he found it in his pocket while packing up his classroom after another empty day without her. The weight of the loss pressed heavily upon him as he reached out to grasp the swinging pendant, tears silently streaming down his cheeks.
Generated Assessment: How dare that kid be so carefree? I see him laughing and smiling with everyone else, and I can't help but feel like an outsider. They're all having fun together, playing games and sharing laughs, while I'm just standing here, trying to hold back my tears. It's like they're enjoying life without even realizing it, whereas I'm stuck inside, drowning in grief. Why does he get to have all this happiness when I’m still grieving? What’s more painful is seeing how happy he looks, especially when he talks about how much fun they’re having. Meanwhile, I'm just sitting there, feeling miserable, and wondering why no one cares about me anymore. Everyone else has moved on, but I’m still stuck in my pain. Even though we were friends, he doesn’t seem to notice; I might as well be invisible. How can he forget about her when I remember everything? That girl meant everything to me, and now that she's gone, I feel lost. But he gets to enjoy life as usual, while I struggle to find meaning. I try to keep going, but every step feels like a burden. I wish I could just disappear and leave this heartache behind. Seeing him makes me feel worse - he thinks nothing of what happened, but for me, every moment feels like torture. How can someone be so free when I’m trapped in sadness? What’s more frustrating is knowing he hasn’t changed since she left. Still the same goofy

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She stood at the kitchen counter, her hands shaking slightly as she chopped onions with more force than necessary. The knife met the wooden board with a rhythmic thud, echoing her frustration. The recipe book was open in front of her, but the words swam before her eyes. She had followed it to the letter, yet the dish tasted... off. Again. She slammed down the knife and sighed deeply, feeling the familiar tightness in her chest. Her husband walked in, looked at her face, and quietly took over the cooking.
Generated Assessment: You know what really gets me? When you think your life is going so well and then things just fall apart. Like, I'm trying to get everything together here. My house is clean, my kids are eating healthy, I'm even making time for hobbies. But noooo, someone has to go and ruin it all. This guy shows up out of nowhere and starts acting like he owns the place. He's got this fake smile plastered on his face and he's telling everyone he's "my new partner." What does that even mean? That we're splitting up? Please, after all I've been through, I'm not about to let some stranger come into our home and start telling me how to live my life. Especially when he's got no idea who I am or what I've been through. Just because he's got some fancy degree doesn't make him qualified to judge me. And don't even get me started on how he thinks he can just waltz in and take over our lives. Newsflash: I put my blood, sweat, and tears into this family, and now you want to just walk in and change everything? No fucking way. You need to understand, I've already lost enough. Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He watches her laugh with colleagues at the staff room, their shared joke echoing in his mind like an alien language. She's never laughed that way with him. He feels the familiar pang of rejection, a knot tightening in his stomach as he turns away, pouring another coffee he doesn't want.
Generated Assessment: Are you fucking kidding me? You're going to let this fucker go because she laughs with others but not with you? You think you're such a great guy just because you're into her, huh? That's rich coming from someone who can't even hold onto a relationship. I'm sick of seeing her smile around other people while she barely cracks a smile when we're together. What kind of sicko needs to hear that she's attractive to others to know they have no chance with her? Do you really need some idiotic proof like that? It's obvious how much better off she'd be with someone else. I bet she's laughing about us right now. She probably is. She thinks she's so funny with her friends, but honestly, it looks pathetic. They're probably making fun of me behind my back, too. Those idiots are probably saying shit like "Look at this loser trying to impress her" or something like that. Why wouldn't they? I'm a failure. This isn't about being jealous; it's about seeing the truth. The fact that she doesn’t look at me is the real issue. She must hate me, and everyone knows it. If I didn’t feel like shit, maybe I could try and understand why she’s not interested, but I don’t need to. I know what I deserve – nothing. At least then I won’t feel stupid for wasting time on her. You know what? This isn’t about getting over her
